It&#039;s hard to get great pide outside of Turkey. It&#039;s hit and miss, even at many Turkish places. Solution: make it yourself! Pide is easier than you think, and it will tick all your pide boxes: pillowy soft bread inside with a crispy base, generous on the toppings. SO GOOD!Makes 2 pide around 40cm / 16&quot; long. A generous meal for 2 people, normal meal for 3 people!TOPPINGS \u2013  Choose only 1. My recipe for whipped cream that I use for &quot;everything&quot;. It&#39;s actually Chantilly cream, the French name for whipped cream that&#39;s lightly sweetened and flavoured with vanilla. Use to decorate cakes, pipe onto cupcakes, dollop on fruit and swirl onto sundaes!\u26a0\ufe0f IMPORTANT:\u00a0You MUST use whipping cream, not pouring cream that cannot be whipped! Check the carton label - they should say if the cream is for whipping. Some readers have had issues with the cream not whipping and I suspect that is the reason. \ud83d\ude22Yield - Cream doubles in volume when whipped. So 1 cup cream (250ml) = 2 cups whipped (500ml).** See separate recipe here for STABILISED WHIPPED CREAM that will hold its form for 2 - 3 days, this is super handy!**", "datePublished": "2022-11-25T15:57:13+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2022/11/Chantilly-cream_5.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2022/11/Chantilly-cream_5.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2022/11/Chantilly-cream_5.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2022/11/Chantilly-cream_5.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["2", "2 cups"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup heavy / thickened cream or whipping cream (, cold - NOT pouring cream! Tender bites of chicken and slippery pieces of sweet leek smothered in a creamy white-wine thyme infused sauce, bubbling under a golden puff pastry crust. Chicken and Leek Pie is comfort food we dream about!I cut my leeks in a specific way. I like larger pieces rather than thinly sliced rings which get too soggy-stringy for my taste. Also, if you don&#39;t like / can&#39;t get puff pastry, cover this pie in mash (like Cottage Pie!) or use a homemade shortcrust pastry.Make one big pie like I&#39;ve done, or ramekins (makes 4 large, 5 regular). It can be drastically simplified - see Notes 1 to 3.SPICINESS: Very mild - just a slight warmth. "caption": "Nagi"}, "description": "I believe you can make great food with everyday ingredients even if you\u2019re short on time and cost conscious. You just need to cook clever and get creative!", "sameAs": ["http://www.recipetineats.com/about-me/"], "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/author/nagi-maehashigmail-com/"}, {"@type": "Recipe", "name": "Paris Mash (Rich & Creamy Mashed Potato)", "author": {"@id": "https://www.recipetineats.com/#/schema/person/1684e6a75e9f91ae2e33ca2de95b47e2"}, "description": "Recipe video above.&nbsp;This is mashed potato as served at top tier restaurants. It's soft and almost pourable, intensely buttery and has a more pure potato flavour. Restaurants double pass the potato through a mill then a fine sieve so it's 100% lump free. For this home version, I simply pass the potato through a ricer OR mash it. Nobody notices the imperfections because they're too focussed on the amazing flavour and the creamy yet fluffy texture!", "datePublished": "2018-12-13T16:00:52+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2018/12/Paris-Mash_Creamy-Mashed-Potato_1.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2018/12/Paris-Mash_Creamy-Mashed-Potato_1.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2018/12/Paris-Mash_Creamy-Mashed-Potato_1.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2018/12/Paris-Mash_Creamy-Mashed-Potato_1.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["6", "6 - 8 people"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT45M", "totalTime": "PT60M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 kg / 2 lb   Dutch Cream, Desiree, Yukon Gold or Maris Piper potatoes (Note 1)", "150 - 200 g / 5 - 7 oz   cold unsalted butter (, cut into 1.5cm / 1/2\" cubes (Note 2))", "1/2 - 3/4 cup (125 - 185ml) milk (, warmed (Note 3))", "Salt", "Softened butter", "Finely chopped parsley"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Scrub potatoes clean.", "name": "Scrub potatoes clean.", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/paris-mash-creamy-mashed-potato/#wprm-recipe-33247-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place potatoes in a large pot and cover with cold water. It&#39;s a vibrant, tart-sweet silky smooth raspberry sauce made simply by simmering berries with a little sugar, blitzing, and straining until smooth. A restaurant favourite!Not all recipes simmer on the stove but I like to because it makes the sauce more syrupy and it combines better so it clings to things and doesn&#39;t &quot;bleed&quot; on the plate. I don&#39;t always strain but I do when I&#39;m cooking to impress, or for refined desserts like Pana Cotta. I&#39;m sharing this recipe as a filling for Pavlova Bombs which is the primary recipe for today. Anything in between = dry, tough meat. This recipe is the Greek way of roasting lamb - slow roasted until tender, braised in a lemon garlic thyme broth that reduces down to a sauce. The sauce is completely different to the thick gravy you are probably used to. This sauce is not thickened with flour, it is lemony, herby and garlicky so it cuts through the richness of the lamb. This is easier and far more foolproof than traditional roast leg of lamb because you don't need to worry about overcooking it.", "datePublished": "2016-03-23T16:00:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2016/03/Greek-Slow-Roast-Lamb_7.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2016/03/Greek-Slow-Roast-Lamb_7.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2016/03/Greek-Slow-Roast-Lamb_7.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2016/03/Greek-Slow-Roast-Lamb_7.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["8"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT420M", "totalTime": "PT430M", "recipeIngredient": ["12 cloves of garlic, peeled", "7 lb / 3.5 kg  leg of lamb (Note 1)", "Salt and pepper", "3 tsp paprika powder", "3 tsp garlic powder (or sub with onion powder)", "2 tbsp olive oil", "2  large onions, quartered (white, brown, yellow, red)", "10  sprigs of thyme", "3  sprigs rosemary", "3 tsp dried oregano", "3  dried bayleaves (or 5 fresh)", "1/2 cup / 125 ml  lemon juice (2 - 3 lemons), plus more to taste", "1 1/2 cups / 375 ml  white wine (or sub with chicken broth/stock, low salt)", "2 cups / 500 ml  chicken broth (liquid chicken stock)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 240\u00b0C/465\u00b0F (220\u00b0C fan). Pork infused with a Vietnamese lemongrass marinade, then cooked over high heat for an authentic char-grill like you get at Vietnamese street stalls! Economical pork shoulder is a tough cut of meat that&#39;s tenderised using a touch of baking soda. Even if you overcook these pork steaks, they are still tender inside!Use to make the popular Vietnamese rice noodle salad, B\u00fan th\u1ecbt n\u01b0\u1edbng, or serve with coconut or jasmine rice and Asian slaw for a lovely dinner.", "datePublished": "2023-04-12T16:05:39+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2023/04/Vietnamese-noodles-lemongrass-pork-1.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2023/04/Vietnamese-noodles-lemongrass-pork-1.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2023/04/Vietnamese-noodles-lemongrass-pork-1.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2023/04/Vietnamese-noodles-lemongrass-pork-1.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT6M", "recipeIngredient": ["500g/1 lb  pork shoulder (, skinless and boneless, or pork scotch (roast or steaks) (Note 1))", "3 tbsp canola oil", "2  lemongrass stalks (, white part only, bruised, cut into 1 cm / 0.4\" slices on angle (Note 2))", "4  garlic cloves (, finely minced)", "4 tbsp lime juice", "3 tbsp fish sauce", "1 tbsp soy sauce ((all purpose or light, NOT dark soy, Note 3))", "4 tbsp brown sugar ((tightly packed tablespoons))", "3 tbsp oil ((canola, vegetable, peanut))", "3/4 tsp baking soda/bi-carb (, for tenderising (Note 4))"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut pork - Cut into 8 equal, thinnish slices of pork. Birria Tacos - or Quesabirria - the legendary crispy red tacos stuffed with cheesy shredded beef dunked in rich consomm\u00e9. This was a beast of a recipe to crack, so I\u2019m thrilled we finally got there. What makes these special: specify chillies by weight not number, toss shredded beef in sauce, skim red-oil off to use for crisping tacos, and our consomm\u00e9 is not watery and thin, it&#39;s a smidge thicker than usual so it clings better.These deliver big flavour with every single bite, the consomm\u00e9 is rich and full bodied with beefy chilli flavour, and wow the tacos are crisp! Important: Birria is very reliant on chillies for flavour. So if you don&#39;t have scales for the chillies, deseed, chop, then measure using cups. Don&#39;t rely on &quot;2 anchos&quot;, they can vary so much in size.", "datePublished": "2025-09-05T16:00:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/09/Birria-tacos_4.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/09/Birria-tacos_4.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/09/Birria-tacos_4.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/09/Birria-tacos_4.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["22", "22 - 25 tacos"], "prepTime": "PT30M", "cookTime": "PT180M", "recipeIngredient": ["25 g (0.9 oz)  guajillo chillies, dried ((~4 pieces, heaped 3/4 cup once chopped) (Note 1))", "45 g (1.6 oz)  ancho chillies, dried ((~2-3 pieces, 1 cup once chopped) (Note 1))", "6 g (0.2 oz)  chillies de arbol, dried ((~6 pieces, 2 tbsp once chopped) (Note 1))", "1/2 cup chilli soaking water ((reserve after simmering))", "5  garlic cloves (, peeled)", "1 small onion (, roughly sliced (~tennis ball size))", "1 medium tomato (, roughly sliced (180g))", "2 tsp dried oregano", "1 tsp ground cumin", "1/8 tsp black pepper", "5 tbsp vegetable oil ((or canola oil) (Note 2))", "1.3 kg/2.6 lb   chuck beef (, cut into 6 large pieces (or boneless beef short ribs - 1.8kg/3.6 lb bone-in) (Note 3))", "2 cups beef stock / broth (, low sodium)", "10  cloves ((or 1/4 tsp ground cloves))", "1  cinnamon stick ((substitute 1/4 tsp powder, but it's not quite the same))", "3  bay leaves (, preferably fresh else dried)", "2 tbsp apple cider vinegar ((or regular white vinegar, red or white wine vinegar))", "2 1/2 tsp cooking salt / kosher salt ((halve for table salt, +30% for flakes))", "1/2 tsp cooking salt / kosher salt", "20 - 25  corn tortillas ((14.5cm/6&quot; wide) (Note 4))", "1  white onion (, diced (Note 5))", "1/2 cup finely chopped coriander / cilantro leaves", "3 1/2 cups (350g)  shredded Colby, Monterey Jack or (Oaxaca cheese (if you can get it) (Note 6))", "Lime wedges (, optional)", "Your favorite salsa or hot sauce (, optional)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "ABBREVIATED RECIPE:", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Simmer chopped chillies 10 min. Strain, blitz Adobo paste. Brown beef, cook off adobo paste, slow-cook beef 2 1/2 hrs (lid on). Remove meat, shred, skim fat off braising liquid (&quot;Birria Oil&quot;). Toss beef in skillet with 1 cup braising liquid (aka Consomme). Heat 1 tsp Birria oil over low heat, wipe pan with tortilla, remove, repeat x2 with 1/2 tsp oil each. Top tortilla with cheese, beef, onion, coriander, fold over, pan fry until crisp. Serve with Birria Consomme for dunking!", "name": "Simmer chopped chillies 10 min. Strain, blitz Adobo paste. Brown beef, cook off adobo paste, slow-cook beef 2 1/2 hrs (lid on). Remove meat, shred, skim fat off braising liquid (&quot;Birria Oil&quot;). Toss beef in skillet with 1 cup braising liquid (aka Consomme). Heat 1 tsp Birria oil over low heat, wipe pan with tortilla, remove, repeat x2 with 1/2 tsp oil each. Top tortilla with cheese, beef, onion, coriander, fold over, pan fry until crisp. Serve with Birria Consomme for dunking!", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/birria-tacos/#wprm-recipe-184692-step-0-0"}]}, {"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "Prepare chillis:", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use gloves if you&#39;re sensitive to working with chilli!", "name": "Use gloves if you&#39;re sensitive to working with chilli!", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/birria-tacos/#wprm-recipe-184692-step-2-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Deseed - Trim and discard stems. I love it, and replicated it so I could serve giant bowls of it when I have friends around. It&#039;s always a hit!BONUS: It stays crispy for days! The secret is clarified butter which is 100% fat, and no water. Normal butter is 15% water so it what makes popcorn soggy. Peach flavour to the max!Serving with ice cream is not optional. The most time-consuming part is chopping the apple because there&#39;s quite a lot of the fruit in this! Yogurt and oil make the crumb beautifully moist so it will stay fresh for days. I like to add walnuts for soft crunch but it&#39;s entirely optional. The apple slice topping is also optional. So many options! :)Want apple muffins instead? Celeriac is an unsung hero of the vegetable world! It makes a wonderful creamy Celeriac Soup that&#039;s an elegant near pure-white colour, and happens to be low carb. It&#039;s thick, creamy and comforting. Texture like potato but better flavour - tastes mildly like celery but with earthy, nutty undertones.Make it as a sophisticated first course for a dinner party, or just a cosy dinner for midweek.This easily makes enough soup for 5 people as a meal (with some crusty bread on the side!)", "datePublished": "2021-03-10T15:00:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/03/Celeriac-Soup_0-SQ.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/03/Celeriac-Soup_0-SQ.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/03/Celeriac-Soup_0-SQ.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/03/Celeriac-Soup_0-SQ.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["5", "5 people"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT45M", "recipeIngredient": ["60g / 4 tbsp  butter (, unsalted)", "2  garlic cloves (, finely chopped)", "1  onion (, diced (brown or yellow))", "1/2  leek (white part only) (, diced into 1cm / \u00bd&quot; cubes (~ 3/4 cup, Note 1))", "3  celery stems (, diced into 1cm / \u00bd&quot; cubes (~1 1/2 cups))", "800g / 1.6 lb (peeled weight) celeriac (, cut into 2cm / \u2158&quot; cubes (~1kg / 2lb unpeeled, Note 2))", "200g / 7oz  potato (, peeled, cut into 2cm / 4/5&quot; cubes (floury or all-rounder \u2013 about  1 large; Note 3))", "1.5 litres / quarts  (6 cups) water (, or stock if you prefer)", "1 1/2 tsp salt", "1/4 tsp white pepper", "1 cup cream (, full fat (pure, thickened or heavy, Note 4))", "1  bay leaf (, fresh)", "2  thyme sprigs", "1/2 tsp black peppercorn ((go without if no sachet))", "1/2 tsp coriander seeds ((1/8 tsp powder if no sachet))", "Croutons ((Note 6))", "Olive oil (, for drizzling)", "1 tbsp chives (, finely chopped (sub parsley or chervil))"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spice and herb sachet: Bundle the bay leaf, thyme, black peppercorns and coriander seeds loosely in a small piece of cheesecloth to create a sachet. A recipe for old school Chinese restaurant style Honey Prawns! This recipe uses a proven method used in my Honey Chicken recipe for Honey Prawns that stays crispy hours even after coating in the sauce!1. Double coating - cornflour/cornstarch to seal in juices, followed by batter.2. Cold batter made with soda water = crispier coating that&#39;s puffy and light, not dense and greasy.3. Cornflour/cornstarch + flour batter - cornflour for ultra crispiness, flour for golden colour.4. Double fry for extra long lasting, thicker crispiness AND less greasy (Asian secret!).5. No-soggy Sauce - glucose or corn syrup to make it &quot;candy like&quot; to stick on the prawn crust rather than soaking in, plus NO WATER in the sauce.Note - the sauce is sweet. That&#39;s the way it&#39;s supposed to be! But not as sickly sweet as many Chinese restaurants tend to be. This is my festive white chocolate rocky road, with add-ins chosen for Christmassy colours as well as flavour combination (glac\u00e9 cherries and coconut is a win!). I like to top it with extra cherries and pistachios to give it an extra special touch. I don&#39;t do that for regular rocky road. Because, you know. Christmas is special! ;)Feel free to switch the add-ins (dried fruits, biscuits, other nuts, raspberries, Turkish delight - see post for lots of other ideas). My rule of thumb is ~4 1/2 cups for every 500g/1 lb chocolate. And don\u2019t skip the oil! Makes the chocolate meltier so it coats everything better, and it\u2019s easier to cut. Coq au Vin \u2013 a true French classic from a true French chef, our very own JB! Chicken pieces are braised in a luscious, glossy red wine sauce with bacon, mushroom and onions that tastes utterly luxurious. Like Beef Bourguignon, the beauty of this dish lies in its simplicity: remarkably few ingredients and simple process with results fit for a king \u2013 or queen! For the best results, start this 2 days before serving: 12 - 24 hour marinade for the chicken (essential), then rest the finished stew overnight to let the flavours develop even further (recommended but not essential).", "datePublished": "2021-09-01T02:00:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/09/Coq-au-Vin_00-SQ.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/09/Coq-au-Vin_00-SQ.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/09/Coq-au-Vin_00-SQ.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/09/Coq-au-Vin_00-SQ.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["4", "4 - 5"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT90M", "totalTime": "PT105M", "recipeIngredient": ["4  chicken thighs (, bone-in, skin on (~220g / 7 oz each) (Note 1))", "4  chicken drumsticks ((Note 1))", "16  pearl onions or picking onions ((Note 2))", "1  bay leaf (, fresh (dry also ok))", "3  thyme sprigs ((sub 1 tsp dried thyme))", "750 ml / 3 cups  pinot noir red wine (, or other dry red wine (Note 3))", "3 - 4 tbsp vegetable oil ((or canola oil))", "3/4 tsp salt ((cooking/kosher salt, or 1/2 tsp table salt))", "1/2 tsp pepper", "400g / 14oz  white mushrooms (, halved (quartered if large) (Note 4))", "150g / 5oz  bacon piece (, (speck) cut into 1 x 2.5cm / 0.4 x 1\" batons (Note 5))", "60g / 4 tbsp  unsalted butter", "3  garlic cloves (, finely minced (with knife))", "2 tbsp tomato paste", "7 tbsp flour (, plain / all purpose)", "750 ml / 3 cups  beef stock", "1/4 tsp salt ((cooking/kosher salt, or 1/8 tsp table salt) (Note 7))", "1/4 tsp black pepper", "2 tbsp parsley (, chopped)", "Mashed potato ((or tagliatelle))"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "Marinate chicken:", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Marinate chicken: Place the Chicken Marinade ingredients in a large glass or ceramic bowl or dish. I've never seen so much love in my boyfriends' eyes as when I opened the steamer to reveal these perfect pork buns. Such an easy recipe to follow and rivals any restaurant for flavour - we don't like them too sweet and found the filling to be nicely balanced. \r\nSimilar to some others I did find that my dough was dry initially, ended up adding ~1/2c extra water to  get consistency right. I afterwards checked the weight/cup conversion and found that 2c of my plain flour is actually 280g rather than 300g - so for anyone trying this I recommend starting with a little less flour and adding if needed as the dough mixes.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Kaleah"}, "datePublished": "2024-01-08"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "So easy to make instructions made simple", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Connie"}, "datePublished": "2023-11-29"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "This is a perfect recipe. I'm Chinese, and I found the wrapper to be very authentic!!!! I don't eat meat so I made my own spicy veg filling (daikon, carrots, onions, cilantro with a garlic sauce that had cornstarch in it so the consistency is sticky like char siu pork). I did not use a stand mixer, just by hand. For the wrappers, the first batch of 4 came out too thin, so the carrot color sort of seeped through. A tip about making the wrapper, I sort of rolled it into a ball, then by hand I sort of made it into a flatter circle, like you would for a pizza dough. It was easier for me that way. Then, I did a little rolling to smooth it out, but I used the back of a spoon to flatten/thin the edges. It was easier than using a big rolling pin. Thin the edges about the same \"depth\" as the pleats. BRINING is the secret to the most succulent, tender roast chicken you will EVER have in your life! Adapted from a recipe by Thomas Keller, one of the great masters of the culinary world. It is tart, salty, a little sweet and beautifully aromatic from the finely minced fresh aromatics mixed in. A little tamarind is what makes this distinctly Thai - it thickens the sauce so it clings to things, and makes it sour. Use leftovers for Pad Thai - it&#39;s an essential ingredient! I like to use this to serve with meats, fish etc - it&#39;s so flavourful, you can use it over a plain piece of cooked fish - though it&#39;s also terrific as a salad dressing or dipping meatballs, spring rolls etc.Makes ~1/2 cup (125 ml)", "datePublished": "2025-11-26T08:11:55+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2015/06/Thai-dipping-sauce_Nam-Jim-jaew-0.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2015/06/Thai-dipping-sauce_Nam-Jim-jaew-0.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2015/06/Thai-dipping-sauce_Nam-Jim-jaew-0.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2015/06/Thai-dipping-sauce_Nam-Jim-jaew-0.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeIngredient": ["1 tbsp tamarind puree ((Note 1))", "2 tbsp fish sauce", "2 tbsp lime juice ((sub 1 1/2 tbsp rice vinegar))", "2 tbsp brown sugar or palm sugar ((shaved))", "1 tbsp hot water", "1 tsp garlic (, very finely minced with a knife)", "1 1/2 tbsp green onion (, very finely minced with a knife)", "1 tbsp eschalots (, very finely minced with a knife (Note 2))", "1/2 - Few things to note, I only got two pans out of the dough but I was using regular everyday baking sheets. I also made the dough in advance and left it in a zip lock bag at room temperature for a good five hours before piping onto the baking sheets and it still came out perfect  The stabilized Chantilly cream makes more than you will ever need. If you need more eclares than what this recipe calls for, just make two choux pastry batches and you will have enough cream for both. I also premade the Chantilly cream with out a mixer and it holds well in the refrigerator for a few hours and honestly is heavenly. The chocolate glaze was pretty straight forward. This amazing quick &amp; easy Thai Coconut Soup is made from scratch!! Tastes like a Thai coconut curry, a cross between Tom Yum and Laksa soups. This recipe is all about the soup broth, so put whatever you want into the soup! The Shredded Chicken and Beef are almost as good (pork is slightly juicier) and stored similarly. The next simplest is Fish Tacos because it's very quick to cook, then just put them in a serving dish and break into chunks with fork. If you want to use one of the chicken recipes to make ahead, use boneless thigh fillets, cook, then keep whole, cover and cool, reserve every drop of leached juice. Madeleines are sweet little French sponge cakes that are as delightful to look at as they are to eat. A recipe taught to me by our resident French Chef JB, these adorable mini butter cakes with their signature shell shape are flavoured with a hint of lemon and make for a lovely afternoon tea, or a pretty finish for any meal. Best served hot and fresh out of the oven. Ricotta pancakes are a step up from plain ones because they are extra soft and fluffy inside. Made famous by Australia&#39;s very own Bill Granger, a signature dish at his popular bistro Bills.Stove control is key, because these are thicker than standard pancakes. Heat too low, and the pancakes will be raw batter inside or won&#39;t rise enough. Too high, and the pancakes will burn before the inside is cooked. Aim for 3 minutes and golden brown surfaces. It&#39;s fine to go over (they will still be moist inside) but if you go under 2 1/2 minutes, they will be raw inside.9 - 10 pancakes (about 13cm/5&quot; in diameter).", "datePublished": "2023-05-12T15:10:18+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2016/03/Ricotta-pancakes_2-SQ.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2016/03/Ricotta-pancakes_2-SQ.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2016/03/Ricotta-pancakes_2-SQ.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2016/03/Ricotta-pancakes_2-SQ.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["9", "9 - 10 pancakes"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT30M", "totalTime": "PT45M", "recipeIngredient": ["3/4 cup ricotta cheese (, full fat (Note 1))", "3  large eggs ((55g/2oz each))", "3 tbsp caster sugar (superfine sugar)", "3/4 cup milk ((full fat best but low fat fine))", "1/2 tsp vanilla extract", "1 tsp white vinegar ((or other clear or clear-ish vinegar, Note 2))", "1 1/3 cups plain/all-purpose flour", "2 tsp baking powder", "1/4 tsp baking soda (bi0carb) (or 3/4 tsp extra baking powder (Note 3))", "Pinch of salt", "1 tbsp (15g)  butter (, melted (Note 4))", "8 oz / 250g   strawberries (, halved or quartered)", "1 tbsp caster/superfine sugar", "Maple syrup (, for dousing)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk wet - Place the Wet ingredients in a bowl and whisk vigorously to combine. Continue cooking, lowering the heat as you go as the pan gets hotter. You should get 9 to 10 in total. Avoiding dry baked turkey breast is notoriously difficult, but this recipe tackles that problem in 2 ways: a) Brining the turkey with a Cajun rub; 2) baking the turkey in the same pan as the Dressing (stuffing), it keeps the turkey moist. Plus the turkey juices gets soaked up by the Dressing. No gravy needed - the Dressing has a golden crust but is so juicy underneath, you don't need gravy. Don't stress if you can't get Andouille sausages - refer to the notes. See Note 4 for adjustment for different Turkey sizes. The recipe was created by rock star LA chef Roy Choi. The flavours of the marinade are classic Cuban, citrusy and strong. It infuses into the pork incredibly well. I made this with boneless pork shoulder because I made it specifically with the intention of using leftovers to make Cubanos (Cuban sandwiches) and boneless is easier to slice. But it can also be made with bone-in pork (add 0.5kg/1lb to the pork weight). This roast is extremely tender though is still suited to carving rather than &quot;pulling apart&quot; with tongs - though I also provide the cook times for a pulled Cuban pork option!", "datePublished": "2015-03-30T21:00:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2015/03/Cuban-Mojo-Marinated-Pork-sliced_680px.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2015/03/Cuban-Mojo-Marinated-Pork-sliced_680px.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2015/03/Cuban-Mojo-Marinated-Pork-sliced_680px.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2015/03/Cuban-Mojo-Marinated-Pork-sliced_680px.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["8", "8 -10"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT180M", "totalTime": "PT195M", "recipeIngredient": ["3/4 cup extra virgin olive oil", "1 cup cilantro / coriander, (lightly packed)", "1 tbsp orange zest", "3/4 cup orange juice, (fresh)", "1/2 cup lime juice", "1/4 cup mint leaves, (lightly packed)", "8  garlic cloves", "1 tbsp fresh oregano leaves, (packed (or 1/2 tbsp dried oregano))", "2 tsp ground cumin", "1 tsp salt", "1 tsp black pepper", "4 lb / 2 kg   pork shoulder / pork butt, (skinless and boneless (not loin or leg roast, will dry out))", "2 tbsp lime juice", "1/4 cup orange juice", "Salt and pepper"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine Marinade ingredients in a food processor and blend until the herbs and garlic are finely chopped. This homestyle Indonesian baked fish recipe is made with a Turmeric Curry Paste slathered on to white fish fillets which are then baked, and served topped with an Indonesian-style tomato salsa called Sambal Tomat.The curry paste is a gorgeously vibrant yellow colour thanks to the turmeric, and packed with fragrant and fresh South-East Asian curry flavours (as opposed to big, in-your-face-spice like Indian curries!).Sambal Tomat comes in all forms, from complex versions with flavourings like shrimp paste, to simpler and fresh ones like this one. "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/75eae612677fdf550ba9a478ea595902153a0a06b8b27aaf6bc3eddcf6367244?s=96&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Ftachyon%2F2024%2F06%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g", "caption": "Nagi"}, "description": "I believe you can make great food with everyday ingredients even if you\u2019re short on time and cost conscious. You just need to cook clever and get creative!", "sameAs": ["http://www.recipetineats.com/about-me/"], "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/author/nagi-maehashigmail-com/"}, {"@type": "Recipe", "name": "How to make glazed ham the day before", "author": {"@id": "https://www.recipetineats.com/#/schema/person/1684e6a75e9f91ae2e33ca2de95b47e2"}, "description": "For years, I\u2019ve been making my glazed ham the day before serving then just reheating it on the day of. It saves so much work on the day - no babysitting the ham and basting, basting, basting!The ham comes out 99% perfectly. The glaze is just as good as freshly made and the ham flesh doesn\u2019t dry out. You can either reheat the ham all the way through (~2 hours) or just reheat the glaze to make it shiny again (~30 - 40 minutes) and leave the inside at room temperature (this is what I do these days). Even if the ham is warm, it&#39;s cool by the time it&#39;s carved/served/eaten, so what&#39;s the difference?! (You can also always briefly microwave the plate of carved ham).Use this make-ahead glazed ham method for either my favourite Maple Glazed Ham or classic Brown Sugar Glazed Ham.", "datePublished": "2022-12-08T15:59:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2022/12/Make-ahead-Glazed-Ham.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2022/12/Make-ahead-Glazed-Ham.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2022/12/Make-ahead-Glazed-Ham.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2022/12/Make-ahead-Glazed-Ham.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT40M", "recipeIngredient": ["Glazed ham recipe of choice ((either half or full ham legs, but bone-in highly recommended rather than boneless, Note 1))"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "The day before:", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake day before \u2013 Make the Maple Glazed Ham or Brown Sugar Glazed Ham the day per the recipe, before when you\u2019ve got time to baby-sit the ham in the oven, basting and brushing as much as needed for the perfect golden glaze.", "name": "Bake day before \u2013 Make the Maple Glazed Ham or Brown Sugar Glazed Ham the day per the recipe, before when you\u2019ve got time to baby-sit the ham in the oven, basting and brushing as much as needed for the perfect golden glaze.", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/how-to-make-glazed-ham-the-day-before/#wprm-recipe-162858-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cool for 2 \u2013 3 hours on the counter until you can barely feel warmth when you hover your hand over the surface. (Whisking time for me: 90 seconds by hand, 30 seconds on Speed 4 electric beater).", "name": "Whisk whites until it&#039;s just opaque, fluffy and creamy.  Do not take it to &quot;stiff peaks&quot;. It should be a consistency so you can draw a figure 8 on the surface and it stays there without sinking. You do not want to be able to do &quot;elf hats&quot; (see in post for photo), that&#039;s too stiff.
